data.reasoning: The menu is extensive and typical of a standard American Chinese restaurant. Traditional Chinese cooking heavily relies on wheat-based soy sauce, thickeners (like wheat flour or cornstarch contaminated by wheat), and fried coatings (batter/breading), all of which contain gluten. Furthermore, items like egg rolls, dumplings, lo mein, and chow fun/mei fun are inherently gluten-containing. There is no explicit mention of gluten-free preparation, dedicated fryer oil, or allergen training, indicating a high risk of cross-contact, especially with shared woks and fryers.
risk_factors: Widespread use of soy sauce (likely contains wheat) in sauces and marinades.
Items like Egg Rolls, Spring Rolls, Fried Wontons, and Lo Mein/Chow Fun noodles are primary gluten sources.
High probability of shared woks and fryers leading to significant cross-contact.
Absence of any stated gluten-free protocols or dedicated preparation areas.
Absence of any review mentions or menu flags confirming gluten safety knowledge.
safe_alternatives: Plain Steamed White Rice or Brown Rice (Must confirm rice is not cooked with broth/sauce containing gluten, which is common in Chinese restaurants).

Healthy Choice Steamed Dishes (D1-D6) - These are advertised as having no oil/sugar/cornstarch, but the diner *must* confirm the accompanying sauce (which must be served on the side and confirmed gluten-free, e.g., using only gluten-free tamari if available, or just plain steamed vegetables/protein). The use of soy sauce in marinades must be ruled out.
Plain Steamed Vegetables (Must verify no wheat-based thickeners or soy sauce were used during preparation or in the 'brown sauce' option).
